1124310.1007/11243.1572-901XTransition Metal ChemistryTransit Met Chem0340-42851572-901XSpringer International PublishingChams11243-016-0055-25510.1007/s11243-016-0055-2ArticleA dual-functional cadmium(II) coordination polymer as a luminescent sensor for selective sensing of iron(III) ions and detecting the temperatureWangKai-Min1DuLin1MaYu-Lu1ZhaoQi-Hua1dgrid.440773.3Key Laboratory of Medicinal Chemistry for Natural Resource Education Ministry, School of Chemical Science and TechnologyYunnan University650091KunmingPeople’s Republic of Chinaqhzhao@ynu.edu.cn66201682016415573580254201619220162542016662016© Springer International Publishing Switzerland 20162016Abstract

A Cd(II) coordination polymer (1), {[Cd2(Ccbp)2(dca)Cl·3H2O]·4H2O} Ccbp− = 4-carboxy-1-(3-carboxybenzyl)pyridin-1-ium and dca− = dicyanamide, has been synthesized via a hydrothermal reaction and fully characterized by single-crystal X-ray structural analysis, FTIR spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction, and thermogravimetric analysis. Complex 1 has a 2D network structure with uncoordinated functional groups. Its solid-state luminescence properties were measured at room temperature. Complex 1 exhibited a high sensitivity for Fe3+ in DMF solutions of mixed metal ions. In addition, the temperature-dependent luminescence properties of 1 have been investigated and show that the complex acts as a luminescent thermometer over a temperature range from 10 to 90 K.

Introduction

Over the last decade, transition metal–organic coordination polymers (CPs), as novel functional materials, have attracted a good deal of attention, not only because of their diverse architectures, but also their potential applications in catalysis [1], gas storage [2], chemical separations [3], nonlinear optics [4], drug delivery [5], luminescence [6], and so on [7–9]. Extensive research has been carried out on the assembly of d10 metal CPs due to their excellent luminescent properties and potential applications as fluorescence probes [10–12]. Over the past few years, a wide range of such luminescent CPs have been developed for the sensing of cations [13], anions [14], small molecules [15], vapors [16], and a few gases [17]. Compared with other methods, fluorescence detection has obvious advantages in terms of high sensitivity, simplicity, short response time, and applicability in both solution and solid phase [18]. The selective detection of iron(III) in solution is particularly important, in view of the importance of iron in the biosphere [19]. To date, a large number of Fe3+ ion probes based on lanthanide CPs have been reported [20–23]. However, probes based on transition metals are more rare [24]. Therefore, there is a need to develop fluorescent chemosensors that are capable of selective sensing of Fe3+ ion.

Temperature-dependent luminescence is a common phenomenon. Luminescent sensors based on CPs can be attractive alternatives for temperature sensing, due to their rapid response, and working capability in strong electric or magnetic fields [25]. Over the past few years, a large number of temperature probes based on CPs have been developed [26, 27]. However, only a small number of these luminescent CP sensors are capable of quantitative temperature detection [28].

In view of the above considerations, the flexible zwitterion 4-carboxy-1-(3-carboxybenzyl)pyridin-1-ium (Ccbp−) and the dicyanamide (dca−) anion have been employed as molecular building blocks together with Cd(II) ions to build a new luminescent coordination polymer (Scheme 1). This 2D coordination polymer, {[Cd2(Ccbp)2(dca)Cl·3H2O]·4H2O} (1), has been synthesized by a hydrothermal reaction. X-ray crystallographic analysis indicates that the structure of complex 1 includes uncoordinated functional groups (N−). The luminescence properties of 1 in the solid state at room temperature and its use for the sensing of Fe3+ ions are described. In addition, temperature-dependent emission spectra of complex 1 have been recorded between 10 and 300 K. To the best of our knowledge, no single Cd2+ coordination polymer exhibiting the dual functionality of simultaneous detection of Fe3+ ion and temperature has been reported to date.

ExperimentalMaterials and methods

All of the synthesis reagents and solvents were purchased from Adamas-beta Corporation Limited and used without further purification, unless otherwise indicated. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DRX400 spectrometer (1H: 400 MHZ, 13C: 100 MHZ); chemical shifts (δ) are expressed in ppm, J values are given in Hz, and deuterated DMSO was used as solvent. IR spectra were recorded on an FTIR Thermo Nicolet Avatar 360 spectrometer using KBr pellets. Inductively coupled plasma spectroscopy (ICP) was performed on a Thermo IRIS Intrepid XSP spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were recorded on a Rigaku Dmax2500 diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere.

Synthesis of 4-carboxy-1-(3-carboxybenzyl)pyridin-1-ium chloride (H<sub>2</sub>CcbpCl)

A mixture of isonicotinic acid (1.231 g, 10 mmol) and methyl 3-(bromomethyl)benzoate (2.291 g, 10 mmol) in CH3CN (50 ml) was refluxed for 5 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting precipitate was filtered off as a white solid. This was dissolved and refluxed in 100 ml of 2 N aqueous HCl for 2 h. After cooling to ambient temperature, the white precipitate was collected by filtration and washed with ether (20 ml × 3) to afford H2CcbpCl (2.780 g, 95 %). 1H NMR (400 Hz, DMSO-d6): δ = 9.43 (d, 2H, ArH, J = 6.4 Hz), 8.51 (d, 2H, ArH, J = 6.4 Hz), 8.19 (s, 1H, ArH), 7.99 (d, 1H, ArH), 7.85 (d, 1H, ArH), 7.61 (t, 1H, ArH), 6.06 (s, 2H, CH2); 13C NMR (100 Hz, DMSO-d6): δ = 167.2, 163.9, 146.7, 146.3, 134.9, 133.9, 132.2, 130.7, 130.5, 130.1, 128.2, 63.4 (Figs. S1, S2). Main IR (KBr, cm−1): 3432(s), 3329(m), 3117(s), 1666(m), 1450(w), 1397(m), 1311(w), 1237(w) (Fig. S3).

Synthesis of {[Cd<sub>2</sub>(Ccbp)<sub>2</sub>(dca)Cl·3H<sub>2</sub>O]·4H<sub>2</sub>O} (<bold>1</bold>)

CdCl2 (0.3 mmol), H2CcbpCl (0.1 mmol), NaOH (0.2 mmol), and sodium dicyanamide (0.1 mmol) were placed in a 15 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave together with 10 ml of H2O. The solution was heated at 120 °C for 48 h and then cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. Colorless block crystals of the product were collected by filtration and washed with water several times and then dried in air (Fig. 1). The obtained yield based on the H2CcbpCl was 51.5 % (45.9 mg). The phase purity of the product was confirmed by PXRD experiments (Fig. 2). The TG curve for complex 1 showed a gradual weight loss of 12.8 % between 120 and 300 °C, which can be ascribed to the removal of three coordinated water ligands and four free water molecules (Fig. S5). Main IR (KBr, cm−1): 3411(s), 3109(m), 3047(m), 2312(w), 2234(w), 2165(s), 1617(s), 1552(m), 1121(w), 886(w) (Fig. S4). The PXRD pattern for complex 1 is shown in Fig. 2. The diffraction peaks of the experimental pattern are in good agreement with the simulated data, indicating that the synthesized bulk material is consistent with the single X-ray crystal structure.

X-ray crystallography

Crystallographic data were collected at 293 K on a Bruker Smart AXS CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using ω-scan technique. Cell parameters were retrieved using SMART software and refined with SAINT on all observed reflections. Absorption corrections were applied with the program SADABS [29]. The structure of complex 1 was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 [30] and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares procedures with SHELXL-97 [30]. All nonhydrogen atoms were located in difference Fourier syntheses and finally refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms attached to the organic moieties were located from either the difference Fourier map or fixed stereochemically. The guest molecules within the pores of the framework were extremely distorted and could not be satisfactorily modeled. The final chemical formula was estimated from the SQUEEZE results combined with the TGA results. Details of the crystallographic data collection and refinement parameters are summarized in Table 1. Main bond lengths and angles are presented in Table 2. CCDC 1452971(1) contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. This information is available free of charge from the Cambridge Structure Database.

Luminescence experiments

The temperature-dependent luminescence properties of complex 1 were studied on an Edinburgh Instrument F920 spectrometer. The excitation and the emission slits were both 5.0 nm, PMT voltage = 700 V. The scan speed was 1200 nm min−1. The spectrometer was left at the set temperature for 30 min in order to allow thermal equilibration before determination of the fluorescence emission spectra.

The luminescence-sensing properties of complex 1 were investigated in DMF suspensions at room temperature. Suspensions of 1 were prepared by introducing the powdered complex (10 mg) into a DMF solution (5.00 ml) of 10−2 M concentrations of MCln (M = K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Al3+, Cr2+, Co2+, Co3+, Ni2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+, Fe2+, Fe3+), respectively. Before photoluminescence measurements, the suspensions were irradiated for 10 min using ultrasonic waves to ensure uniform dispersion.

Results and discussionCrystal structure of complex <bold>1</bold>

Complex 1 was soluble in DMSO, but insoluble in DMF, H2O, CH3OH, CH3CN. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis shows that complex 1 crystallized in the Pna21 space group. As shown in Fig. 1a, there are two crystallographically independent Cd(II) atoms (Cd1 and Cd2). The pseudo-octahedral coordination geometry of Cd1 is provided by one cyano nitrogen (N4), two oxygens from water ligands (O9 and O10), and three oxygens from carboxylates (O1, O7, and O8), while Cd2 assumes a pseudo-octahedral coordination geometry defined by one cyano nitrogen atom (N5), one chloride ligand (Cl1), one oxygen from a water ligand (O12), and three oxygens from carboxylates (O3, O4, and O5). The Cd–N/O bond distances for both Cd1 and Cd2 fall in the range between 2.231(3) and 2.581(3) Å, which are close to those reported in other Cd-CPs [31]. Additionally, Cd1 is linked to Cd2 via two μ2–η2:η1 bidentate carboxylate groups to form helical chains running along the b axis, with a pitch of 16.09 Å. The helical chains are bridged by the μ1,5-dca− ligand to form a 2D network (Fig. 1b).

Luminescent chemical sensing

Considering that previous studies have shown that Cd2+ CPs can exhibit luminescent properties [32], the luminescence spectra of the free ligand and an as-synthesized solid sample of complex 1 were investigated at room temperature under excitation at 272 and 286 nm, respectively (Fig. 3). The emission spectrum of the free H2CcbpCl ligand exhibits two broad bands at 424 and 475 nm (Fig. 3). Similar to the free ligand, complex 1 displayed emission peaks at 408 and 465 nm, and the blueshifts and reduced intensities of these bands probably originate from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) [33, 34].

In order to investigate the properties of complex 1 for sensing metal ions, the luminescence enhancement effects of various metal ions [MCln; M = K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Al3+, Cr2+, Co2+, Co3+, Ni2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+, Fe2+, Fe3+] on 1 in an 10−2 M DMF suspension were investigated under excitation at 286 nm (Fig. 4a). The luminescence intensity was significantly quenched on the addition of the Fe3+ ion in solution compared to the blank sample, while other metal ions only slightly affect the luminescence intensity. The quenching effect may be largely ascribed to the interactions between the Fe3+ ion and the N− uncoordinated group of complex 1. This would allow electrons to transfer from 1 to Fe3+, resulting in a less effective intramolecular energy transfer from the ligands to the Cd(II). A similar mechanism has been proposed for other systems [35, 36]. The selectivity of the system was further studied using different ion mixtures in DMF solution. The luminescence of 1 was slightly weakened by mixed ions in the absence of Fe3+ (Fig. 4b); however, the luminescence was immediately and completely quenched by the addition of Fe3+ to the mixture. Hence, complex 1 has high selectivity for Fe3+ over other metal ions. The PXRD pattern of complex 1 after sensing Fe3+ was in good agreement with the as-synthesized sample, demonstrating that the basic framework remains unchanged after sensing (Fig. S6). Moreover, ICP experiments were performed to monitor the release of Cd2+ ions from complex 1 after the Fe3+ ion sensing experiment and the concentration of Cd2+ ions was found to be 0.17 μg ml−1, which is close to that of the blank sample (0.16 μg ml−1). Therefore, it can be concluded that there is no release of Cd2+ from complex 1 during the sensing experiments and that the framework of the complex remains unchanged.

To better understand the sensing ability toward Fe3+ titration, further experiments were carried out. As shown in Fig. 5a, the fluorescence intensities gradually decreased with increasing concentration of Fe3+. The quenching effect can be rationalized at low concentrations by the Stern–Volmer equation:Io/I=1+Ksv×[M]\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ I_{\text{o}} /I = 1 \, + K_{\text{sv}} \times [M] $$\end{document}

Where Io and I are the luminescence intensities of ethanol suspensions of complex 1 before and after the addition of Fe3+ ion, respectively, Ksv is the quenching constant, and [M] is the molar concentration of Fe3+ [37]. The linear correlation coefficient (R) for the Ksv curve of complex 1 with Fe3+ concentration is 0.9973 (Fig. 5b), showing that the fluorescence quenching effect is a good fit to the Stern–Volmer model. The value of Ksv is 7.094 × 103 M−1 at low concentrations of Fe3+, which is comparable to those of previously reported MOF-based sensors, such as Zn-CP-bpe (2.395 × 103 M−1) [15], Cd-CP (2.0 × 104 M−1) [38] and Zn-MOF (2.146 × 103 M−1) [39].

Temperature-dependent luminescence thermometer

The temperature-dependent luminescence intensity of complex 1 was investigated (Fig. S7) in order to establish its potential as a luminescent thermometer. Figure 6a, b shows the temperature-dependent emission spectra of complex 1 at different temperatures (10–300 K). The intensity of the emissions at 408 nm decreases gradually as the temperature increases. Cooling the sample should limit the thermally activated intramolecular rotations and nonradiative-decay pathways [40, 41]. Importantly, the luminescence intensity of complex 1 decreased in a linear fashion over the temperature change from 10 to 90 K (R2 = 0.9906). Among previously reported the CPs, only very rare examples can detect temperature changes with such an excellent linear response from 10 to 90 K [28].

Conclusions

In summary, a new dual-functional luminescent sensor Cd-CP has been synthesized by the hydrothermal method based on Ccbp− and dicyanamide ligands. The complex shows a high sensitivity as a luminescent thermometer with a good linear response between 10 and 90 K. Hence, this complex can be considered as the first potential dual-functional luminescent sensing material for both Fe3+ and temperature. Further studies on related complexes are under way in our laboratory.

Luminescent sensors based on CPs can be attractive alternatives for temperature sensing, due to their rapid response, and working capability in strong electric or magnetic fields [25]. Over the past few years, a large number of temperature probes based on CPs have been developed [26, 27]. However, only a small number of these luminescent CP sensors are capable of quantitative temperature detection [28].In view of the above considerations, the flexible zwitterion 4-carboxy-1-(3-carboxybenzyl)pyridin-1-ium (Ccbp-) and the dicyanamide (dca-) anion have been employed as molecular building blocks together with Cd(II) ions to build a new luminescent coordination polymer (Scheme 1). This 2D coordination polymer, {[Cd2(Ccbp)2(dca)Cl⋅3H2O]⋅4H2O} (1), has been synthesized by a hydrothermal reaction. X-ray crystallographic analysis indicates that the structure of complex 1 includes uncoordinated functional groups (N-). The luminescence properties of 1 in the solid state at room temperature and its use for the sensing of Fe3+ ions are described. In addition, temperature-dependent emission spectra of complex 1 have been recorded between 10 and 300 K. To the best of our knowledge, no single Cd2+ coordination polymer exhibiting the dual functionality of simultaneous detection of Fe3+ ion and temperature has been reported to date.ExperimentalMaterials and methodsAll of the synthesis reagents and solvents were purchased from Adamas-beta Corporation Limited and used without further purification, unless otherwise indicated. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DRX400 spectrometer (1H: 400 MHZ, 13C: 100 MHZ); chemical shifts (δ) are expressed in ppm, J values are given in Hz, and deuterated DMSO was used as solvent. IR spectra were recorded on an FTIR Thermo Nicolet Avatar 360 spectrometer using KBr pellets. Inductively coupled plasma spectroscopy (ICP) was performed on a Thermo IRIS Intrepid XSP spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were recorded on a Rigaku Dmax2500 diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere.Synthesis of 4-carboxy-1-(3-carboxybenzyl)pyridin-1-ium chloride (H2CcbpCl)A mixture of isonicotinic acid (1.231 g, 10 mmol) and methyl 3-(bromomethyl)benzoate (2.291 g, 10 mmol) in CH3CN (50 ml) was refluxed for 5 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting precipitate was filtered off as a white solid. This was dissolved and refluxed in 100 ml of 2 N aqueous HCl for 2 h. After cooling to ambient temperature, the white precipitate was collected by filtration and washed with ether (20 ml × 3) to afford H2CcbpCl (2.780 g, 95 %). 1H NMR (400 Hz, DMSO-d6): δ = 9.43 (d, 2H, ArH, J = 6.4 Hz), 8.51 (d, 2H, ArH, J = 6.4 Hz), 8.19 (s, 1H, ArH), 7.99 (d, 1H, ArH), 7.85 (d, 1H, ArH), 7.61 (t, 1H, ArH), 6.06 (s, 2H, CH2); 13C NMR (100 Hz, DMSO-d6): δ = 167.2, 163.9, 146.7, 146.3, 134.9, 133.9, 132.2, 130.7, 130.5, 130.1, 128.2, 63.4 (Figs. S1, S2). Main IR (KBr, cm-1): 3432(s), 3329(m), 3117(s), 1666(m), 1450(w), 1397(m), 1311(w), 1237(w) (Fig. S3).Synthesis of {[Cd2(Ccbp)2(dca)Cl⋅3H2O]⋅4H2O} (1)CdCl2 (0.3 mmol), H2CcbpCl (0.1 mmol), NaOH (0.2 mmol), and sodium dicyanamide (0.1 mmol) were placed in a 15 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave together with 10 ml of H2O. The solution was heated at 120 °C for 48 h and then cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. Colorless block crystals of the product were collected by filtration and washed with water several times and then dried in air (Fig. 1). The obtained yield based on the H2CcbpCl was 51.5 % (45.9 mg). The phase purity of the product was confirmed by PXRD experiments (Fig. 2). The TG curve for complex 1 showed a gradual weight loss of 12.8 % between 120 and 300 °C, which can be ascribed to the removal of three coordinated water ligands and four free water molecules (Fig. S5). Main IR (KBr, cm-1): 3411(s), 3109(m), 3047(m), 2312(w), 2234(w), 2165(s), 1617(s), 1552(m), 1121(w), 886(w) (Fig. S4). The PXRD pattern for complex 1 is shown in Fig. 2. The diffraction peaks of the experimental pattern are in good agreement with the simulated data, indicating that the synthesized bulk material is consistent with the single X-ray crystal structure.X-ray crystallographyCrystallographic data were collected at 293 K on a Bruker Smart AXS CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using ω-scan technique. Cell parameters were retrieved using SMART software and refined with SAINT on all observed reflections. Absorption corrections were applied with the program SADABS [29]. The structure of complex 1 was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 [30] and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares procedures with SHELXL-97 [30]. All nonhydrogen atoms were located in difference Fourier syntheses and finally refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms attached to the organic moieties were located from either the difference Fourier map or fixed stereochemically. The guest molecules within the pores of the framework were extremely distorted and could not be satisfactorily modeled. The final chemical formula was estimated from the SQUEEZE results combined with the TGA results. Details of the crystallographic data collection and refinement parameters are summarized in Table 1. Main bond lengths and angles are presented in Table 2. CCDC 1452971(1) contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. This information is available free of charge from the Cambridge Structure Database.Luminescence experimentsThe temperature-dependent luminescence properties of complex 1 were studied on an Edinburgh Instrument F920 spectrometer. The excitation and the emission slits were both 5.0 nm, PMT voltage = 700 V. The scan speed was 1200 nm min-1. The spectrometer was left at the set temperature for 30 min in order to allow thermal equilibration before determination of the fluorescence emission spectra.The luminescence-sensing properties of complex 1 were investigated in DMF suspensions at room temperature. Suspensions of 1 were prepared by introducing the powdered complex (10 mg) into a DMF solution (5.00 ml) of 10-2 M concentrations of MCln (M = K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Al3+, Cr2+, Co2+, Co3+, Ni2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+, Fe2+, Fe3+), respectively. Before photoluminescence measurements, the suspensions were irradiated for 10 min using ultrasonic waves to ensure uniform dispersion.Results and discussionCrystal structure of complex 1Complex 1 was soluble in DMSO, but insoluble in DMF, H2O, CH3OH, CH3CN. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis shows that complex 1 crystallized in the Pna21 space group. As shown in Fig. 1a, there are two crystallographically independent Cd(II) atoms (Cd1 and Cd2). The pseudo-octahedral coordination geometry of Cd1 is provided by one cyano nitrogen (N4), two oxygens from water ligands (O9 and O10), and three oxygens from carboxylates (O1, O7, and O8), while Cd2 assumes a pseudo-octahedral coordination geometry defined by one cyano nitrogen atom (N5), one chloride ligand (Cl1), one oxygen from a water ligand (O12), and three oxygens from carboxylates (O3, O4, and O5). The Cd-N/O bond distances for both Cd1 and Cd2 fall in the range between 2.231(3) and 2.581(3) Å, which are close to those reported in other Cd-CPs [31]. Additionally, Cd1 is linked to Cd2 via two μ2-η2:η1 bidentate carboxylate groups to form helical chains running along the b axis, with a pitch of 16.09 Å. The helical chains are bridged by the μ1,5-dca- ligand to form a 2D network (Fig. 1b).Luminescent chemical sensingConsidering that previous studies have shown that Cd2+ CPs can exhibit luminescent properties [32], the luminescence spectra of the free ligand and an as-synthesized solid sample of complex 1 were investigated at room temperature under excitation at 272 and 286 nm, respectively (Fig. 3). The emission spectrum of the free H2CcbpCl ligand exhibits two broad bands at 424 and 475 nm (Fig. 3). Similar to the free ligand, complex 1 displayed emission peaks at 408 and 465 nm, and the blueshifts and reduced intensities of these bands probably originate from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) [33, 34].In order to investigate the properties of complex 1 for sensing metal ions, the luminescence enhancement effects of various metal ions [MCln; M = K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Al3+, Cr2+, Co2+, Co3+, Ni2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+, Fe2+, Fe3+] on 1 in an 10-2 M DMF suspension were investigated under excitation at 286 nm (Fig. 4a). The luminescence intensity was significantly quenched on the addition of the Fe3+ ion in solution compared to the blank sample, while other metal ions only slightly affect the luminescence intensity. The quenching effect may be largely ascribed to the interactions between the Fe3+ ion and the N- uncoordinated group of complex 1. This would allow electrons to transfer from 1 to Fe3+, resulting in a less effective intramolecular energy transfer from the ligands to the Cd(II). A similar mechanism has been proposed for other systems [35, 36]. The selectivity of the system was further studied using different ion mixtures in DMF solution. The luminescence of 1 was slightly weakened by mixed ions in the absence of Fe3+ (Fig. 4b); however, the luminescence was immediately and completely quenched by the addition of Fe3+ to the mixture. Hence, complex 1 has high selectivity for Fe3+ over other metal ions. The PXRD pattern of complex 1 after sensing Fe3+ was in good agreement with the as-synthesized sample, demonstrating that the basic framework remains unchanged after sensing (Fig. S6). Moreover, ICP experiments were performed to monitor the release of Cd2+ ions from complex 1 after the Fe3+ ion sensing experiment and the concentration of Cd2+ ions was found to be 0.17 μg ml-1, which is close to that of the blank sample (0.16 μg ml-1). Therefore, it can be concluded that there is no release of Cd2+ from complex 1 during the sensing experiments and that the framework of the complex remains unchanged.To better understand the sensing ability toward Fe3+ titration, further experiments were carried out. As shown in Fig. 5a, the fluorescence intensities gradually decreased with increasing concentration of Fe3+. The quenching effect can be rationalized at low concentrations by the Stern-Volmer equation:Io/I=1+Ksv×[M]\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$ I_{\text{o}} /I = 1 \, + K_{\text{sv}} \times [M] $$\end{document}Where Io and I are the luminescence intensities of ethanol suspensions of complex 1 before and after the addition of Fe3+ ion, respectively, Ksv is the quenching constant, and [M] is the molar concentration of Fe3+ [37]. The linear correlation coefficient (R) for the Ksv curve of complex 1 with Fe3+ concentration is 0.9973 (Fig. 5b), showing that the fluorescence quenching effect is a good fit to the Stern-Volmer model. The value of Ksv is 7.094 × 103 M-1 at low concentrations of Fe3+, which is comparable to those of previously reported MOF-based sensors, such as Zn-CP-bpe (2.395 × 103 M-1) [15], Cd-CP (2.0 × 104 M-1) [38] and Zn-MOF (2.146 × 103 M-1) [39].Temperature-dependent luminescence thermometerThe temperature-dependent luminescence intensity of complex 1 was investigated (Fig. S7) in order to establish its potential as a luminescent thermometer. Figure 6a, b shows the temperature-dependent emission spectra of complex 1 at different temperatures (10-300 K). The intensity of the emissions at 408 nm decreases gradually as the temperature increases. Cooling the sample should limit the thermally activated intramolecular rotations and nonradiative-decay pathways [40, 41]. Importantly, the luminescence intensity of complex 1 decreased in a linear fashion over the temperature change from 10 to 90 K (R2 = 0.9906). Among previously reported the CPs, only very rare examples can detect temperature changes with such an excellent linear response from 10 to 90 K [28].ConclusionsIn summary, a new dual-functional luminescent sensor Cd-CP has been synthesized by the hydrothermal method based on Ccbp- and dicyanamide ligands. The complex shows a high sensitivity as a luminescent thermometer with a good linear response between 10 and 90 K. Hence, this complex can be considered as the first potential dual-functional luminescent sensing material for both Fe3+ and temperature. Further studies on related complexes are under way in our laboratory.Supporting informationCCDC 1452971 (1) contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. NMR spectra of ligand, FTIR spectroscopy, TGA diagrams, and the PXRD patterns can be found in the supporting information.AcknowledgmentsThis work was supported by the National Natural Science elements.content: A Cd(II) coordination polymer (1), {[Cd2(Ccbp)2(dca)Cl·3H2O]·4H2O} Ccbp− = 4-carboxy-1-(3-carboxybenzyl)pyridin-1-ium and dca− = dicyanamide, has been synthesized via a hydrothermal reaction and fully characterized by single-crystal X-ray structural analysis, FTIR spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction, and thermogravimetric analysis. Complex 1 has a 2D network structure with uncoordinated functional groups. Its solid-state luminescence properties were measured at room temperature. Complex 1 exhibited a high sensitivity for Fe3+ in DMF solutions of mixed metal ions. In addition, the temperature-dependent luminescence properties of 1 have been investigated and show that the complex acts as a luminescent thermometer over a temperature range from 10 to 90 K.

Abstract

A Cd(II) coordination polymer (1), {[Cd2(Ccbp)2(dca)Cl⋅3H2O]⋅4H2O} Ccbp- = 4-carboxy-1-(3-carboxybenzyl)pyridin-1-ium and dca- = dicyanamide, has been synthesized via a hydrothermal reaction and fully characterized by single-crystal X-ray structural analysis, FTIR spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction, and thermogravimetric analysis. Complex 1 has a 2D network structure with uncoordinated functional groups. Its solid-state luminescence properties were measured at room temperature. Complex 1 exhibited a high sensitivity for Fe3+ in DMF solutions of mixed metal ions. In addition, the temperature-dependent luminescence properties of 1 have been investigated and show that the complex acts as a luminescent thermometer over a temperature range from 10 to 90 K.

elements.content: Over the last decade, transition metal–organic coordination polymers (CPs), as novel functional materials, have attracted a good deal of attention, not only because of their diverse architectures, but also their potential applications in catalysis [1], gas storage [2], chemical separations [3], nonlinear optics [4], drug delivery [5], luminescence [6], and so on [7–9]. Extensive research has been carried out on the assembly of d10 metal CPs due to their excellent luminescent properties and potential applications as fluorescence probes [10–12]. Over the past few years, a wide range of such luminescent CPs have been developed for the sensing of cations [13], anions [14], small molecules [15], vapors [16], and a few gases [17]. Compared with other methods, fluorescence detection has obvious advantages in terms of high sensitivity, simplicity, short response time, and applicability in both solution and solid phase [18]. The selective detection of iron(III) in solution is particularly important, in view of the importance of iron in the biosphere [19]. To date, a large number of Fe3+ ion probes based on lanthanide CPs have been reported [20–23]. However, probes based on transition metals are more rare [24]. Therefore, there is a need to develop fluorescent chemosensors that are capable of selective sensing of Fe3+ ion.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the last decade, transition metal-organic coordination polymers (CPs), as novel functional materials, have attracted a good deal of attention, not only because of their diverse architectures, but also their potential applications in catalysis [1], gas storage [2], chemical separations [3], nonlinear optics [4], drug delivery [5], luminescence [6], and so on [7-9]. Extensive research has been carried out on the assembly of d10 metal CPs due to their excellent luminescent properties and potential applications as fluorescence probes [10-12]. Over the past few years, a wide range of such luminescent CPs have been developed for the sensing of cations [13], anions [14], small molecules [15], vapors [16], and a few gases [17]. Compared with other methods, fluorescence detection has obvious advantages in terms of high sensitivity, simplicity, short response time, and applicability in both solution and solid phase [18]. The selective detection of iron(III) in solution is particularly important, in view of the importance of iron in the biosphere [19]. To date, a large number of Fe3+ ion probes based on lanthanide CPs have been reported [20-23]. However, probes based on transition metals are more rare [24]. Therefore, there is a need to develop fluorescent chemosensors that are capable of selective sensing of Fe3+ ion.

However, only a small number of these luminescent CP sensors are capable of quantitative temperature detection [28].

Experimental

Materials and methods

All of the synthesis reagents and solvents were purchased from Adamas-beta Corporation Limited and used without further purification, unless otherwise indicated. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DRX400 spectrometer (1H: 400 MHZ, 13C: 100 MHZ); chemical shifts (δ) are expressed in ppm, J values are given in Hz, and deuterated DMSO was used as solvent. IR spectra were recorded on an FTIR Thermo Nicolet Avatar 360 spectrometer using KBr pellets. Inductively coupled plasma spectroscopy (ICP) was performed on a Thermo IRIS Intrepid XSP spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were recorded on a Rigaku Dmax2500 diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere.

elements.content: A mixture of isonicotinic acid (1.231 g, 10 mmol) and methyl 3-(bromomethyl)benzoate (2.291 g, 10 mmol) in CH3CN (50 ml) was refluxed for 5 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting precipitate was filtered off as a white solid. This was dissolved and refluxed in 100 ml of 2 N aqueous HCl for 2 h. After cooling to ambient temperature, the white precipitate was collected by filtration and washed with ether (20 ml × 3) to afford H2CcbpCl (2.780 g, 95 %). 1H NMR (400 Hz, DMSO-d6): δ = 9.43 (d, 2H, ArH, J = 6.4 Hz), 8.51 (d, 2H, ArH, J = 6.4 Hz), 8.19 (s, 1H, ArH), 7.99 (d, 1H, ArH), 7.85 (d, 1H, ArH), 7.61 (t, 1H, ArH), 6.06 (s, 2H, CH2); 13C NMR (100 Hz, DMSO-d6): δ = 167.2, 163.9, 146.7, 146.3, 134.9, 133.9, 132.2, 130.7, 130.5, 130.1, 128.2, 63.4 (Figs. S1, S2). Main IR (KBr, cm−1): 3432(s), 3329(m), 3117(s), 1666(m), 1450(w), 1397(m), 1311(w), 1237(w) (Fig. S3).

Synthesis of 4-carboxy-1-(3-carboxybenzyl)pyridin-1-ium chloride (H2CcbpCl)

A mixture of isonicotinic acid (1.231 g, 10 mmol) and methyl 3-(bromomethyl)benzoate (2.291 g, 10 mmol) in CH3CN (50 ml) was refluxed for 5 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting precipitate was filtered off as a white solid. This was dissolved and refluxed in 100 ml of 2 N aqueous HCl for 2 h. After cooling to ambient temperature, the white precipitate was collected by filtration and washed with ether (20 ml × 3) to afford H2CcbpCl (2.780 g, 95 %). 1H NMR (400 Hz, DMSO-d6): δ = 9.43 (d, 2H, ArH, J = 6.4 Hz), 8.51 (d, 2H, ArH, J = 6.4 Hz), 8.19 (s, 1H, ArH), 7.99 (d, 1H, ArH), 7.85 (d, 1H, ArH), 7.61 (t, 1H, ArH), 6.06 (s, 2H, CH2); 13C NMR (100 Hz, DMSO-d6): δ = 167.2, 163.9, 146.7, 146.3, 134.9, 133.9, 132.2, 130.7, 130.5, 130.1, 128.2, 63.4 (Figs. S1, S2). Main IR (KBr, cm-1): 3432(s), 3329(m), 3117(s), 1666(m), 1450(w), 1397(m), 1311(w), 1237(w) (Fig. S3).

elements.content: CdCl2 (0.3 mmol), H2CcbpCl (0.1 mmol), NaOH (0.2 mmol), and sodium dicyanamide (0.1 mmol) were placed in a 15 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave together with 10 ml of H2O. The solution was heated at 120 °C for 48 h and then cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. Colorless block crystals of the product were collected by filtration and washed with water several times and then dried in air (Fig. 1). The obtained yield based on the H2CcbpCl was 51.5 % (45.9 mg). The phase purity of the product was confirmed by PXRD experiments (Fig. 2). The TG curve for complex 1 showed a gradual weight loss of 12.8 % between 120 and 300 °C, which can be ascribed to the removal of three coordinated water ligands and four free water molecules (Fig. S5). Main IR (KBr, cm−1): 3411(s), 3109(m), 3047(m), 2312(w), 2234(w), 2165(s), 1617(s), 1552(m), 1121(w), 886(w) (Fig. S4). The PXRD pattern for complex 1 is shown in Fig. 2. The diffraction peaks of the experimental pattern are in good agreement with the simulated data, indicating that the synthesized bulk material is consistent with the single X-ray crystal structure.

CdCl2 (0.3 mmol), H2CcbpCl (0.1 mmol), NaOH (0.2 mmol), and sodium dicyanamide (0.1 mmol) were placed in a 15 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave together with 10 ml of H2O. The solution was heated at 120 °C for 48 h and then cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. Colorless block crystals of the product were collected by filtration and washed with water several times and then dried in air (Fig. 1). The obtained yield based on the H2CcbpCl was 51.5 % (45.9 mg). The phase purity of the product was confirmed by PXRD experiments (Fig. 2). The TG curve for complex 1 showed a gradual weight loss of 12.8 % between 120 and 300 °C, which can be ascribed to the removal of three coordinated water ligands and four free water molecules (Fig. S5). Main IR (KBr, cm-1): 3411(s), 3109(m), 3047(m), 2312(w), 2234(w), 2165(s), 1617(s), 1552(m), 1121(w), 886(w) (Fig. S4). The PXRD pattern for complex 1 is shown in Fig. 2. The diffraction peaks of the experimental pattern are in good agreement with the simulated data, indicating that the synthesized bulk material is consistent with the single X-ray crystal structure.

elements.content: Crystallographic data were collected at 293 K on a Bruker Smart AXS CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using ω-scan technique. Cell parameters were retrieved using SMART software and refined with SAINT on all observed reflections. Absorption corrections were applied with the program SADABS [29]. The structure of complex 1 was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 [30] and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares procedures with SHELXL-97 [30]. All nonhydrogen atoms were located in difference Fourier syntheses and finally refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms attached to the organic moieties were located from either the difference Fourier map or fixed stereochemically. The guest molecules within the pores of the framework were extremely distorted and could not be satisfactorily modeled. The final chemical formula was estimated from the SQUEEZE results combined with the TGA results. Details of the crystallographic data collection and refinement parameters are summarized in Table 1. Main bond lengths and angles are presented in Table 2. CCDC 1452971(1) contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. This information is available free of charge from the Cambridge Structure Database.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Crystallographic data were collected at 293 K on a Bruker Smart AXS CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using ω-scan technique. Cell parameters were retrieved using SMART software and refined with SAINT on all observed reflections. Absorption corrections were applied with the program SADABS [29]. The structure of complex 1 was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 [30] and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares procedures with SHELXL-97 [30]. All nonhydrogen atoms were located in difference Fourier syntheses and finally refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms attached to the organic moieties were located from either the difference Fourier map or fixed stereochemically. The guest molecules within the pores of the framework were extremely distorted and could not be satisfactorily modeled. The final chemical formula was estimated from the SQUEEZE results combined with the TGA results. Details of the crystallographic data collection and refinement parameters are summarized in Table 1. Main bond lengths and angles are presented in Table 2. CCDC 1452971(1) contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. This information is available free of charge from the Cambridge Structure Database.

The temperature-dependent luminescence properties of complex 1 were studied on an Edinburgh Instrument F920 spectrometer. The excitation and the emission slits were both 5.0 nm, PMT voltage = 700 V. The scan speed was 1200 nm min−1. The spectrometer was left at the set temperature for 30 min in order to allow thermal equilibration before determination of the fluorescence emission spectra.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence experiments

The temperature-dependent luminescence properties of complex 1 were studied on an Edinburgh Instrument F920 spectrometer. The excitation and the emission slits were both 5.0 nm, PMT voltage = 700 V. The scan speed was 1200 nm min-1. The spectrometer was left at the set temperature for 30 min in order to allow thermal equilibration before determination of the fluorescence emission spectra.

elements.content: The luminescence-sensing properties of complex 1 were investigated in DMF suspensions at room temperature. Suspensions of 1 were prepared by introducing the powdered complex (10 mg) into a DMF solution (5.00 ml) of 10−2 M concentrations of MCln (M = K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Al3+, Cr2+, Co2+, Co3+, Ni2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+, Fe2+, Fe3+), respectively. Before photoluminescence measurements, the suspensions were irradiated for 10 min using ultrasonic waves to ensure uniform dispersion.

Before photoluminescence measurements, the suspensions were irradiated for 10 min using ultrasonic waves to ensure uniform dispersion.

elements.content: Complex 1 was soluble in DMSO, but insoluble in DMF, H2O, CH3OH, CH3CN. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis shows that complex 1 crystallized in the Pna21 space group. As shown in Fig. 1a, there are two crystallographically independent Cd(II) atoms (Cd1 and Cd2). The pseudo-octahedral coordination geometry of Cd1 is provided by one cyano nitrogen (N4), two oxygens from water ligands (O9 and O10), and three oxygens from carboxylates (O1, O7, and O8), while Cd2 assumes a pseudo-octahedral coordination geometry defined by one cyano nitrogen atom (N5), one chloride ligand (Cl1), one oxygen from a water ligand (O12), and three oxygens from carboxylates (O3, O4, and O5). The Cd–N/O bond distances for both Cd1 and Cd2 fall in the range between 2.231(3) and 2.581(3) Å, which are close to those reported in other Cd-CPs [31]. Additionally, Cd1 is linked to Cd2 via two μ2–η2:η1 bidentate carboxylate groups to form helical chains running along the b axis, with a pitch of 16.09 Å. The helical chains are bridged by the μ1,5-dca− ligand to form a 2D network (Fig. 1b).
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal structure of complex 1

Complex 1 was soluble in DMSO, but insoluble in DMF, H2O, CH3OH, CH3CN. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis shows that complex 1 crystallized in the Pna21 space group. As shown in Fig. 1a, there are two crystallographically independent Cd(II) atoms (Cd1 and Cd2). The pseudo-octahedral coordination geometry of Cd1 is provided by one cyano nitrogen (N4), two oxygens from water ligands (O9 and O10), and three oxygens from carboxylates (O1, O7, and O8), while Cd2 assumes a pseudo-octahedral coordination geometry defined by one cyano nitrogen atom (N5), one chloride ligand (Cl1), one oxygen from a water ligand (O12), and three oxygens from carboxylates (O3, O4, and O5). The Cd-N/O bond distances for both Cd1 and Cd2 fall in the range between 2.231(3) and 2.581(3) Å, which are close to those reported in other Cd-CPs [31]. Additionally, Cd1 is linked to Cd2 via two μ2-η2:η1 bidentate carboxylate groups to form helical chains running along the b axis, with a pitch of 16.09 Å. The helical chains are bridged by the μ1,5-dca- ligand to form a 2D network (Fig. 1b).

elements.content: Considering that previous studies have shown that Cd2+ CPs can exhibit luminescent properties [32], the luminescence spectra of the free ligand and an as-synthesized solid sample of complex 1 were investigated at room temperature under excitation at 272 and 286 nm, respectively (Fig. 3). The emission spectrum of the free H2CcbpCl ligand exhibits two broad bands at 424 and 475 nm (Fig. 3). Similar to the free ligand, complex 1 displayed emission peaks at 408 and 465 nm, and the blueshifts and reduced intensities of these bands probably originate from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) [33, 34].
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent chemical sensing

Considering that previous studies have shown that Cd2+ CPs can exhibit luminescent properties [32], the luminescence spectra of the free ligand and an as-synthesized solid sample of complex 1 were investigated at room temperature under excitation at 272 and 286 nm, respectively (Fig. 3). The emission spectrum of the free H2CcbpCl ligand exhibits two broad bands at 424 and 475 nm (Fig. 3). Similar to the free ligand, complex 1 displayed emission peaks at 408 and 465 nm, and the blueshifts and reduced intensities of these bands probably originate from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) [33, 34].

elements.content: In order to investigate the properties of complex 1 for sensing metal ions, the luminescence enhancement effects of various metal ions [MCln; M = K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Al3+, Cr2+, Co2+, Co3+, Ni2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+, Fe2+, Fe3+] on 1 in an 10−2 M DMF suspension were investigated under excitation at 286 nm (Fig. 4a). The luminescence intensity was significantly quenched on the addition of the Fe3+ ion in solution compared to the blank sample, while other metal ions only slightly affect the luminescence intensity. The quenching effect may be largely ascribed to the interactions between the Fe3+ ion and the N− uncoordinated group of complex 1. This would allow electrons to transfer from 1 to Fe3+, resulting in a less effective intramolecular energy transfer from the ligands to the Cd(II). A similar mechanism has been proposed for other systems [35, 36]. The selectivity of the system was further studied using different ion mixtures in DMF solution. The luminescence of 1 was slightly weakened by mixed ions in the absence of Fe3+ (Fig. 4b); however, the luminescence was immediately and completely quenched by the addition of Fe3+ to the mixture. Hence, complex 1 has high selectivity for Fe3+ over other metal ions. The PXRD pattern of complex 1 after sensing Fe3+ was in good agreement with the as-synthesized sample, demonstrating that the basic framework remains unchanged after sensing (Fig. S6). Moreover, ICP experiments were performed to monitor the release of Cd2+ ions from complex 1 after the Fe3+ ion sensing experiment and the concentration of Cd2+ ions was found to be 0.17 μg ml−1, which is close to that of the blank sample (0.16 μg ml−1). Therefore, it can be concluded that there is no release of Cd2+ from complex 1 during the sensing experiments and that the framework of the complex remains unchanged.

elements.content: Where Io and I are the luminescence intensities of ethanol suspensions of complex 1 before and after the addition of Fe3+ ion, respectively, Ksv is the quenching constant, and [M] is the molar concentration of Fe3+ [37]. The linear correlation coefficient (R) for the Ksv curve of complex 1 with Fe3+ concentration is 0.9973 (Fig. 5b), showing that the fluorescence quenching effect is a good fit to the Stern–Volmer model. The value of Ksv is 7.094 × 103 M−1 at low concentrations of Fe3+, which is comparable to those of previously reported MOF-based sensors, such as Zn-CP-bpe (2.395 × 103 M−1) [15], Cd-CP (2.0 × 104 M−1) [38] and Zn-MOF (2.146 × 103 M−1) [39].

elements.content: The temperature-dependent luminescence intensity of complex 1 was investigated (Fig. S7) in order to establish its potential as a luminescent thermometer. Figure 6a, b shows the temperature-dependent emission spectra of complex 1 at different temperatures (10–300 K). The intensity of the emissions at 408 nm decreases gradually as the temperature increases. Cooling the sample should limit the thermally activated intramolecular rotations and nonradiative-decay pathways [40, 41]. Importantly, the luminescence intensity of complex 1 decreased in a linear fashion over the temperature change from 10 to 90 K (R2 = 0.9906). Among previously reported the CPs, only very rare examples can detect temperature changes with such an excellent linear response from 10 to 90 K [28].
elements.clean_text:
Temperature-dependent luminescence thermometer

The temperature-dependent luminescence intensity of complex 1 was investigated (Fig. S7) in order to establish its potential as a luminescent thermometer. Figure 6a, b shows the temperature-dependent emission spectra of complex 1 at different temperatures (10-300 K). The intensity of the emissions at 408 nm decreases gradually as the temperature increases. Cooling the sample should limit the thermally activated intramolecular rotations and nonradiative-decay pathways [40, 41]. Importantly, the luminescence intensity of complex 1 decreased in a linear fashion over the temperature change from 10 to 90 K (R2 = 0.9906). Among previously reported the CPs, only very rare examples can detect temperature changes with such an excellent linear response from 10 to 90 K [28].

elements.content: In summary, a new dual-functional luminescent sensor Cd-CP has been synthesized by the hydrothermal method based on Ccbp− and dicyanamide ligands. The complex shows a high sensitivity as a luminescent thermometer with a good linear response between 10 and 90 K. Hence, this complex can be considered as the first potential dual-functional luminescent sensing material for both Fe3+ and temperature. Further studies on related complexes are under way in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a new dual-functional luminescent sensor Cd-CP has been synthesized by the hydrothermal method based on Ccbp- and dicyanamide ligands. The complex shows a high sensitivity as a luminescent thermometer with a good linear response between 10 and 90 K. Hence, this complex can be considered as the first potential dual-functional luminescent sensing material for both Fe3+ and temperature. Further studies on related complexes are under way in our laboratory.

NMR spectra of ligand, FTIR spectroscopy, TGA diagrams, and the PXRD patterns can be found in the supporting information.

A mixture of isonicotinic acid (1.231 g, 10 mmol) and methyl 3-(bromomethyl)benzoate (2.291 g, 10 mmol) in CH3CN (50 ml) was refluxed for 5 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting precipitate was filtered off as a white solid. This was dissolved and refluxed in 100 ml of 2 N aqueous HCl for 2 h. After cooling to ambient temperature, the white precipitate was collected by filtration and washed with ether (20 ml × 3) to afford H2CcbpCl (2.780 g, 95 %). 1H NMR (400 Hz, DMSO-d6): δ = 9.43 (d, 2H, ArH, J = 6.4 Hz), 8.51 (d, 2H, ArH, J = 6.4 Hz), 8.19 (s, 1H, ArH), 7.99 (d, 1H, ArH), 7.85 (d, 1H, ArH), 7.61 (t, 1H, ArH), 6.06 (s, 2H, CH2); 13C NMR (100 Hz, DMSO-d6): δ = 167.2, 163.9, 146.7, 146.3, 134.9, 133.9, 132.2, 130.7, 130.5, 130.1, 128.2, 63.4 (Figs. S1, S2). Main IR (KBr, cm−1): 3432(s), 3329(m), 3117(s), 1666(m), 1450(w), 1397(m), 1311(w), 1237(w) (Fig. S3).

Synthesis of {[Cd<sub>2</sub>(Ccbp)<sub>2</sub>(dca)Cl·3H<sub>2</sub>O]·4H<sub>2</sub>O} (<bold>1</bold>)

CdCl2 (0.3 mmol), H2CcbpCl (0.1 mmol), NaOH (0.2 mmol), and sodium dicyanamide (0.1 mmol) were placed in a 15 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave together with 10 ml of H2O. The solution was heated at 120 °C for 48 h and then cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. Colorless block crystals of the product were collected by filtration and washed with water several times and then dried in air (Fig. 1). The obtained yield based on the H2CcbpCl was 51.5 % (45.9 mg). The phase purity of the product was confirmed by PXRD experiments (Fig. 2). The TG curve for complex 1 showed a gradual weight loss of 12.8 % between 120 and 300 °C, which can be ascribed to the removal of three coordinated water ligands and four free water molecules (Fig. S5). Main IR (KBr, cm−1): 3411(s), 3109(m), 3047(m), 2312(w), 2234(w), 2165(s), 1617(s), 1552(m), 1121(w), 886(w) (Fig. S4). The PXRD pattern for complex 1 is shown in Fig. 2. The diffraction peaks of the experimental pattern are in good agreement with the simulated data, indicating that the synthesized bulk material is consistent with the single X-ray crystal structure.

Synthesis of 4-carboxy-1-(3-carboxybenzyl)pyridin-1-ium chloride (H2CcbpCl)

A mixture of isonicotinic acid (1.231 g, 10 mmol) and methyl 3-(bromomethyl)benzoate (2.291 g, 10 mmol) in CH3CN (50 ml) was refluxed for 5 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting precipitate was filtered off as a white solid. This was dissolved and refluxed in 100 ml of 2 N aqueous HCl for 2 h. After cooling to ambient temperature, the white precipitate was collected by filtration and washed with ether (20 ml × 3) to afford H2CcbpCl (2.780 g, 95 %). 1H NMR (400 Hz, DMSO-d6): δ = 9.43 (d, 2H, ArH, J = 6.4 Hz), 8.51 (d, 2H, ArH, J = 6.4 Hz), 8.19 (s, 1H, ArH), 7.99 (d, 1H, ArH), 7.85 (d, 1H, ArH), 7.61 (t, 1H, ArH), 6.06 (s, 2H, CH2); 13C NMR (100 Hz, DMSO-d6): δ = 167.2, 163.9, 146.7, 146.3, 134.9, 133.9, 132.2, 130.7, 130.5, 130.1, 128.2, 63.4 (Figs. S1, S2). Main IR (KBr, cm-1): 3432(s), 3329(m), 3117(s), 1666(m), 1450(w), 1397(m), 1311(w), 1237(w) (Fig. S3).

CdCl2 (0.3 mmol), H2CcbpCl (0.1 mmol), NaOH (0.2 mmol), and sodium dicyanamide (0.1 mmol) were placed in a 15 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave together with 10 ml of H2O. cln_elements.content:
Considering that previous studies have shown that Cd2+ CPs can exhibit luminescent properties [32], the luminescence spectra of the free ligand and an as-synthesized solid sample of complex 1 were investigated at room temperature under excitation at 272 and 286 nm, respectively (Fig. 3). The emission spectrum of the free H2CcbpCl ligand exhibits two broad bands at 424 and 475 nm (Fig. 3). Similar to the free ligand, complex 1 displayed emission peaks at 408 and 465 nm, and the blueshifts and reduced intensities of these bands probably originate from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) [33, 34].

In order to investigate the properties of complex 1 for sensing metal ions, the luminescence enhancement effects of various metal ions [MCln; M = K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Al3+, Cr2+, Co2+, Co3+, Ni2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+, Fe2+, Fe3+] on 1 in an 10−2 M DMF suspension were investigated under excitation at 286 nm (Fig. 4a). The luminescence intensity was significantly quenched on the addition of the Fe3+ ion in solution compared to the blank sample, while other metal ions only slightly affect the luminescence intensity. The quenching effect may be largely ascribed to the interactions between the Fe3+ ion and the N− uncoordinated group of complex 1. This would allow electrons to transfer from 1 to Fe3+, resulting in a less effective intramolecular energy transfer from the ligands to the Cd(II). A similar mechanism has been proposed for other systems [35, 36]. The selectivity of the system was further studied using different ion mixtures in DMF solution. The luminescence of 1 was slightly weakened by mixed ions in the absence of Fe3+ (Fig. 4b); however, the luminescence was immediately and completely quenched by the addition of Fe3+ to the mixture. Hence, complex 1 has high selectivity for Fe3+ over other metal ions. The PXRD pattern of complex 1 after sensing Fe3+ was in good agreement with the as-synthesized sample, demonstrating that the basic framework remains unchanged after sensing (Fig. S6). Moreover, ICP experiments were performed to monitor the release of Cd2+ ions from complex 1 after the Fe3+ ion sensing experiment and the concentration of Cd2+ ions was found to be 0.17 μg ml−1, which is close to that of the blank sample (0.16 μg ml−1). Therefore, it can be concluded that there is no release of Cd2+ from complex 1 during the sensing experiments and that the framework of the complex remains unchanged.

Where Io and I are the luminescence intensities of ethanol suspensions of complex 1 before and after the addition of Fe3+ ion, respectively, Ksv is the quenching constant, and [M] is the molar concentration of Fe3+ [37]. The linear correlation coefficient (R) for the Ksv curve of complex 1 with Fe3+ concentration is 0.9973 (Fig. 5b), showing that the fluorescence quenching effect is a good fit to the Stern–Volmer model. The value of Ksv is 7.094 × 103 M−1 at low concentrations of Fe3+, which is comparable to those of previously reported MOF-based sensors, such as Zn-CP-bpe (2.395 × 103 M−1) [15], Cd-CP (2.0 × 104 M−1) [38] and Zn-MOF (2.146 × 103 M−1) [39].

Temperature-dependent luminescence thermometer

The temperature-dependent luminescence intensity of complex 1 was investigated (Fig. S7) in order to establish its potential as a luminescent thermometer. Figure 6a, b shows the temperature-dependent emission spectra of complex 1 at different temperatures (10–300 K). The intensity of the emissions at 408 nm decreases gradually as the temperature increases. Cooling the sample should limit the thermally activated intramolecular rotations and nonradiative-decay pathways [40, 41]. Importantly, the luminescence intensity of complex 1 decreased in a linear fashion over the temperature change from 10 to 90 K (R2 = 0.9906). Among previously reported the CPs, only very rare examples can detect temperature changes with such an excellent linear response from 10 to 90 K [28].

The linear correlation coefficient (R) for the Ksv curve of complex 1 with Fe3+ concentration is 0.9973 (Fig. 5b), showing that the fluorescence quenching effect is a good fit to the Stern-Volmer model.
